articles.headline: Faster Pace by China on Rise in Currency
articles.snippet: China dramatically stepped up the appreciation of its currency, allowing it to push through an important level against the dollar for the first time.
articles.abstract: China dramatically stepped up the appreciation of its currency, allowing it to push through an important level against the dollar for the first time.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: In Teeming India, Water Crisis Means Dry Pipes and Foul Sludge
articles.snippet: A crisis decades in the making has reduced middle-class people in New Delhi to foraging for water.
articles.abstract: A crisis decades in the making has reduced middle-class people in New Delhi to foraging for water.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Sept. 28 — The quest for water can drive a woman mad.

articles.headline: Selling Shares by the Billions to Racing Fans
articles.snippet: The story of a tiny company that spent the little money it had on sponsoring a race car sheds light on the market for small stocks that can fly below the radar for years.
articles.abstract: The story of a tiny company that spent the little money it had on sponsoring a race car sheds light on the market for small stocks that can fly below the radar for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Was this stock being traded by crooks? Should the brokers have noticed? How about the regulators, who now charge that the brokers missed “red flags” but may have missed a few themselves.

articles.headline: H.P. Before a Skeptical Congress
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard’s top executives tried to explain why they did not question the legality of an internal spying operation.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard’s top executives tried to explain why they did not question the legality of an internal spying operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 — Hewlett-Packard’s former chairwoman and its current leader faced an admonishing and sometimes incredulous House subcommittee on Thursday as they tried to explain why they never questioned the legal foundation of an internal spying operation.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: New Sense of Caution at F.D.A.
articles.snippet: Many drug company executives say the F.D.A. has quietly become more assertive about keeping new drugs off the market.
articles.abstract: Many drug company executives say the F.D.A. has quietly become more assertive about keeping new drugs off the market.

articles.headline: Hewlett’s Hunt for Leak Became a Game of Clue
articles.snippet: The company’s sleuths produced an 18-page report that reads at times like a whodunit, at other times like a dissertation.
articles.abstract: The company’s sleuths produced an 18-page report that reads at times like a whodunit, at other times like a dissertation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 — They were looking for an academic. The suspect was conversant in computer chip technology. And he would have to be the kind of person who used the word “pooped” to mean tired.

articles.headline: Kerkorian Pushes G.M. for Renault-Nissan Deal
articles.snippet: The billionaire investor said he was willing to spend another $400 million in stock to pressure G.M. to explore an alliance with Renault and Nissan.
articles.abstract: The billionaire investor said he was willing to spend another $400 million in stock to pressure G.M. to explore an alliance with Renault and Nissan.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 28 — Talk is not cheap, after all.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Selling Shares by the Billions to Racing Fans
articles.snippet: Was this stock being traded by crooks? Should the brokers have noticed? How about the regulators, who now charge that the brokers missed ''red flags'' but may have missed a few themselves.     The story of a tiny Nevada company that claimed to be ...
articles.abstract: Was this stock being traded by crooks? Should the brokers have noticed? How about the regulators, who now charge that the brokers missed ''red flags'' but may have missed a few themselves.     The story of a tiny Nevada company that claimed to be in the diamond mining business but spent the little money it had on sponsoring a race car, sheds light on the market for small stocks that can fly below the radar for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Was this stock being traded by crooks? Should the brokers have noticed? How about the regulators, who now charge that the brokers missed "red flags" but may have missed a few themselves.

articles.headline: Kerkorian Pushes G.M. for Renault-Nissan Deal
articles.snippet: Talk is not cheap, after all.     Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor, said Thursday that he was willing to spend another $400 million on General Motors stock in an apparent bid to pressure G.M. to redouble its efforts to explore a possible a...
articles.abstract: Talk is not cheap, after all.     Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire investor, said Thursday that he was willing to spend another $400 million on General Motors stock in an apparent bid to pressure G.M. to redouble its efforts to explore a possible alliance with Renault and Nissan.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 28 - Talk is not cheap, after all.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: New Sense of Caution at F.D.A.
articles.snippet: A federal advisory group last week derided the Food and Drug Administration as a feckless watchdog unable to protect consumers from unsafe medicines. But try telling that to drug company executives, investors and analysts.      Many of them say th...
articles.abstract: A federal advisory group last week derided the Food and Drug Administration as a feckless watchdog unable to protect consumers from unsafe medicines. But try telling that to drug company executives, investors and analysts.      Many of them say the F.D.A. has already responded to a barrage of criticism over the last two years by quietly becoming more assertive about keeping new drugs off the market or refusing to approve new uses for existing medications.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal advisory group last week derided the Food and Drug Administration as a feckless watchdog unable to protect consumers from unsafe medicines. But try telling that to drug company executives, investors and analysts.

articles.headline: H.P. Before a Skeptical Congress
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman and its current leader faced an admonishing and sometimes incredulous House subcommittee on Thursday as they tried to explain why they never questioned the legal foundation of an internal spying operation.     T...
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman and its current leader faced an admonishing and sometimes incredulous House subcommittee on Thursday as they tried to explain why they never questioned the legal foundation of an internal spying operation.     The former chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, who authorized the operation but said repeatedly that she was not its supervisor, came under especially harsh scrutiny because she refused to express contrition when invited to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman and its current leader faced an admonishing and sometimes incredulous House subcommittee on Thursday as they tried to explain why they never questioned the legal foundation of an internal spying operation.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Senate Approves Broad New Rules to Try Detainees
articles.snippet: The Senate approved a measure on Thursday on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects, establishing far-reaching rules to deal with what President Bush has called the most dangerous combatants in a different type of war.      The vote w...
articles.abstract: The Senate approved a measure on Thursday on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects, establishing far-reaching rules to deal with what President Bush has called the most dangerous combatants in a different type of war.      The vote was 65 to 34. It was cast after more than 10 hours of often impassioned debate that touched on the Constitution, the horrors of Sept. 11 and the role of the United States in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 - The Senate approved a measure on Thursday on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects, establishing far-reaching rules to deal with what President Bush has called the most dangerous combatants in a different type of war.

articles.headline: Counsel Resigns
articles.snippet: Ann O. Baskins, left, the Hewlett-Packard general counsel, has resigned. She was one of 10 witnesses who declined to answer questions from a House committee. Page C6.
articles.abstract: Ann O. Baskins, left, the Hewlett-Packard general counsel, has resigned. She was one of 10 witnesses who declined to answer questions from a House committee. Page C6.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ann O. Baskins, left, the Hewlett-Packard general counsel, has resigned. She was one of 10 witnesses who declined to answer questions from a House committee. Page C6.

articles.headline: Faster Pace by China on Rise in Currency
articles.snippet: It's been just days since Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. returned from China, but already the Chinese government has sharply stepped up the appreciation of its currency, allowing it to push through an important level against the dollar on...
articles.abstract: It's been just days since Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. returned from China, but already the Chinese government has sharply stepped up the appreciation of its currency, allowing it to push through an important level against the dollar on Thursday for the first time.     The recent climb -- less than a full percentage point since the beginning of September -- is still modest and perhaps will not last. But it is producing cautious hope in the Bush administration that the Chinese government may be lifting its opposition to a revaluation that could ease China's huge trade surplus with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Sept. 28 - It's been just days since Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. returned from China, but already the Chinese government has sharply stepped up the appreciation of its currency, allowing it to push through an important level against the dollar on Thursday for the first time.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: Hewlett’s Hunt for Leak Became a Game of Clue
articles.snippet: They were looking for an academic. The suspect was conversant in computer chip technology. And he would have to be the kind of person who used the word ''pooped'' to mean tired.     In a case right out of CSI: Corporate America, a team of private ...
articles.abstract: They were looking for an academic. The suspect was conversant in computer chip technology. And he would have to be the kind of person who used the word ''pooped'' to mean tired.     In a case right out of CSI: Corporate America, a team of private investigators spent months obsessively hunting the source of a news leak from inside Hewlett-Packard about the company's corporate strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 - They were looking for an academic. The suspect was conversant in computer chip technology. And he would have to be the kind of person who used the word "pooped" to mean tired.

articles.headline: In Teeming India, Water Crisis Means Dry Pipes and Foul Sludge
articles.snippet: The quest for water can drive a woman mad.      Ask Ritu Prasher. Every day, Mrs. Prasher, a homemaker in a middle-class neighborhood of this capital, rises at 6:30 a.m. and begins fretting about water.
articles.abstract: The quest for water can drive a woman mad.      Ask Ritu Prasher. Every day, Mrs. Prasher, a homemaker in a middle-class neighborhood of this capital, rises at 6:30 a.m. and begins fretting about water.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Sept. 28 - The quest for water can drive a woman mad.

articles.headline: New Woodward Book Says Bush Ignored Urgent Warning on Iraq
articles.snippet: The White House ignored an urgent warning in September 2003 from a top Iraq adviser who said that thousands of additional American troops were desperately needed to quell the insurgency there, according to a new book by Bob Woodward, the Washingto...
articles.abstract: The White House ignored an urgent warning in September 2003 from a top Iraq adviser who said that thousands of additional American troops were desperately needed to quell the insurgency there, according to a new book by Bob Woodward, the Washington Post reporter and author. The book describes a White House riven by dysfunction and division over the war.      The warning is described in ''State of Denial,'' scheduled for publication on Monday by Simon & Schuster. The book says President Bush's top advisers were often at odds among themselves, and sometimes were barely on speaking terms, but shared a tendency to dismiss as too pessimistic assessments from American commanders and others about the situation in Iraq.
